text.p: These are the leading stories in the Kenyan press on Monday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- A Nairobi university student leader is killed in a mysterious explosion barely a week after receiving death threats.
- A terror gang goes on rampage in the outskirts of Nairobi along the Thika-Nairobi highway.
- Opposition parliamentarian Kennedy Kiliku will table a report in London on ethnic violence in Kenya.
- Highway robbers open fire on a van along the Thika-Nairobi highway causing it to overturn and killing three people.
- Controversial cleric Timothy Njoya says only re-colonisation by the British can eradicate perennial famine in the country and establish a semblance of civilisation.
- An assistant chief in Western Kenya evades a police trap after escaping prison custody.
- Over 1.9 million flamingoes have migrated from Lake Nakuru to neighbouring lakes in the Rift Valley because of drought.
- Five people are arrested in Meru for being in possesion of seven bags of famine relief food.
- The government dispels fears that the coming general election will be marred by irregularities and violence.
- President Yoweri Museveni of Uganda declined an American request to give Zaire's rebel leader Laurent Kabila a ride on his plane to talks in South Africa last week.
- An environmental advisory committee in South Africa is sacked for its repeated attacks on business tycoon Ketan Somaia's controversial South African parks deal.

- Kenya moves swiftly to avert a diplomatic row with Uganda over arrested spokesman for the Lord's Resistance Army Dominic Wanyama, by handing him over to the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees.
